blocks.text: Maxwell's model is a very convenient form of compound vibrator, and is utilized to determine the modulus of rigidity of the system to which it is supported. It constitutes essentially of a tube along which weights may be moved from one section to another, the movement being a definite amplitude.

Let  
        $m_1$ = the mass of each of the movable weights  
        $m_2$ = the mass of each of the fixed weights.

Then the time period $T$ of oscillations is measured when the movable weights are placed as shown, and it can be proved that the modulus of rigidity $G$ may be related to the modulus of rigidity through the moment of inertia under the conditions of conditions.
Thus, since $m_1$ is shifted from the position $A$ to $B$ due to the change of the C.G. of $I_1$ from a distance $d$ relative to the axis of oscillation for $I_1$ when $m_1$ is unaltered.

If this means the length of $I_1$ is altered, let us assume a quantity for $I_2$ considering the changes due to $m_1$ being altered again, the two masses  
        $I_1 = m_1[l^2]$  
        $I_2 = (m_1 - m_2)l^2 + m_2(16R^2)$.
Example 43â€”Find the moment of inertia of a sphere of radius $R$ about its diameter.
